5,40,40,80,"Set your own trigger properties and receive them as ""state""","Triggers can be set and are converted to a state object using dot notation with : representing the = operator, so you can make your own triggers as you choose (text based trigger)

percentOfScrollyTellerThatIsAwesome:100

5,40,40,80,Using Scroll Progress,"We can also use a progress variable (0-1) in combination with setting our own triggers to handle data ranges or anything else related to the graph. Here we set xStart and xEnd variables in the trigger, and can then use the progress variable to update a graphical element smoothly as a narration proceeds.

xStart:1;xEnd:500;

(see: onScrollFunction() in the file: demo_app/exampleSection0/ exampleSection0.js of the ScrollyTeller repo)",,,"{ ""code"": ""onScroll"" }",,onScrollFunction() in ScrollyTeller configuration,onScrollFunction is triggered upon every scroll event,

5,40,40,80,Referring to progress in styles,"You can also refer to the current progress using $progress in the style triggers, so to fade the container in as scrolling progresses downward, we would use a trigger like this:

containerStyle.opacity:$progress",,,"{

5,40,40,80,Referring to progress in styles,"And to fade the container out a scrolling progresses downward, we would use a trigger like this:

containerStyle.opacity:calc(1 - $progress)

(Notice that this special case requires spaces within the calc() function, which is just the CSS calc() function. $progress is replaced by the current progress value)",,,"{
